title: Ed Woodward opens up on Man Utd's transfer market frustration
text:

Manchester United executive vice-chairman Ed Woodward has opened up on the their transfer window frustration of being used by players.

Woodward hinted they track the players who use links with the club for their own means, saying the number peaked at 250 players five seasons ago and generally sees around 200 names linked each year.

He revealed that number is in stark contrast with the number of players actually on their radar - usually in single figure - and is something they are "wary of" as a club.

Woodward opened up on the situation they face when asked about their summer interest in Bruno Fernandes, who eventually stayed put at Sporting Lisbon.

(Image: PA Wire)

Asked by United We Stand if Fernandes used the club for his own means, Woodward said: "It hit a peak five seasons ago with 250 players.

"It was 177 two seasons ago. It's around 200 every year.

"We're usually after three players, so we might be talking to nine in reality.

"What you are referring to in the original question does happen, but it's less likely to happen give our closed-door approach to recruitment targets.

"But it does exist and we have to be wary of that [players using the club].

(Image: SIPA USA/PA Images)

"Sometimes, the amount of time a player or his agent invests into discussions, meetings and contracts shows that there is an interest.

"If it was only a flippant interest then they could go and put a fake story then go to a club president and go say 'Look at who is in for me.' That happens all the time as well.

"What sometimes also happens is that we do have a player in an agreed position, but his club refuse to sell and, because the club refuse to sell, the player then uses that to get a new contract.

"From our perspective, we have to try and see through it and make sure that the club is not being used.

"We don't waste time, we're more robust."
description: Man Utd chief Ed Woodward has given an insight into the frustration they often face in the transfer market
